Courses: Certificate I in Business
Description: This entry-level qualification allows individuals across a variety of industry sectors to develop basic skills and knowledge to prepare for work. They may undertake a range of simple tasks under close supervision. The range of technical skills and knowledge is limited.
Career outcomes: No Specific Job Role but is the starting point to careers in office administration environments.
Subject or unit name 1: Contribute to health and safety of self and others
Subject or unit name 4: Work effectively in a business environment
Subject or unit name 5: Operate a personal digital device
Subject or unit name 6: Develop keyboard skills

Courses: Certificate II in Business
Description: This qualification reflects the role of individuals in a variety of junior administrative positions who perform a range of mainly routine tasks using limited practical skills and fundamental operational knowledge in a defined context. Individuals in these roles generally work under direct supervision.
Career outcomes: The following job roles are defined for this course: / International Education Office Receptionist, / Legal Receptionist, / Administration Officer (Local Government), / Office Assistant, / Receptionist, / Administrative Assistant, / Information Desk Clerk, / Clerical Officer, / Data Entry Operator
Subject or unit name 1: Contribute to health and safety of self and others
Subject or unit name 4: Handle mail
Subject or unit name 5: Contribute to workplace innovation
Subject or unit name 6: Produce simple word processed documents
Subject or unit name 7: Create and use spreadsheets
Subject or unit name 8: Participate in environmentally sustainable work practices
Subject or unit name 9: Manage personal stress in the workplace
Subject or unit name 10: Organise and complete daily work activities

Courses: Certificate III in Business
Description: This qualification reflects the varied roles of individuals across different industry sectors who apply a broad range of competencies using some discretion, judgment and relevant theoretical knowledge. They may provide technical advice and support to a team.
Career outcomes: The following job roles are defined for this course: / Word Processing Operator / Information Officer / Data Entry Operator / Customer Service Officer / Payroll Officer / Clerical Officer
Subject or unit name 1: Apply knowledge of WHS legislation in the workplace
Subject or unit name 4: Perform financial calculations
Subject or unit name 5: Promote innovation in a team environment
Subject or unit name 6: Use simple relational databases
Subject or unit name 7: Create electronic presentations
Subject or unit name 9: Design and produce digital text documents
Subject or unit name 10: Develop keyboarding speed and accuracy

Courses: Certificate IV in Business
Description: This qualification is suitable for individuals working as board members, contact officers and senior staff within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations. It also applies to public servants working with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander boards of governance.
Career outcomes: The following job roles are defined for this course: / Executive Director, / Indigenous Organisation Board Member, / Non-Executive Director, / Board Member, / Board Secretary
Subject or unit name 1: Maintain and protect cultural values in the organisation
Subject or unit name 2: Undertake the roles and responsibilities of a board member
Subject or unit name 4: Oversee organisational planning
Subject or unit name 5: Implement organisational plans
Subject or unit name 6: Oversee financial management
Subject or unit name 7: Contribute to the development and implementation of organisational policies
Subject or unit name 9: Manage a board meeting
Subject or unit name 10: Participate effectively as a board member

Courses: Certificate III in Community Services
Description: This qualification reflects the role of entry level community services workers who support individuals through the provision of person-centred services. Work may include day-to-day support of individuals in community settings or support the implementation of specific communitybased programs
Career outcomes: Residential Support Worker / Aboriginal Intake and Referral Worker / Community care worker / Client Contact,Aboriginal Community Development Worker / Welfare Support Worker / Support Worker (Community Services)
Subject or unit name 1: Respond to client’s needs
Subject or unit name 2: Communicate and work in health or community services
Subject or unit name 3: Follow safe work practices for direct client care
Subject or unit name 4: Work with diverse people
Subject or unit name 5: Manage personal stressors in the work environment
Subject or unit name 6: Provide individualised support
Subject or unit name 7: Provide loss and grief support.
Subject or unit name 8: Recognise and respond to crisis situations
Subject or unit name 9: Recognise and respond appropriately to domestic and family violence
Subject or unit name 10: Provide parenting, health and well-being education

Courses: Certificate I in Construction
Description: This qualification provides an introduction to the construction industry, its culture, occupations, job roles and workplace expectations. The units of competency cover essential work health and safety requirements, the industrial and work organisation structure, communication skills, work planning, and basic use of tools and materials. The qualification is built around a basic construction project unit that integrates the skills and embeds the facets of employability skills in context.
Career outcomes: Construction assistant
Subject or unit name 1: Work effectively and sustainably in the construction industry
Subject or unit name 4: Read and interpret plans and specifications
Subject or unit name 5: Use construction tools and equipment
Subject or unit name 6: Work safely in the construction industry
Subject or unit name 7: Apply OHS requirements, policies and procedures in the construction industry

Courses: Certificate II in Construction
Description: This qualification provides an occupational outcome and a range of support tasks applicable to a majority of construction work sites. The qualification has core units of competency that are required in many Certificate III qualifications. The elective options are structured to allow choice from a range of units aligned at Certificate III level and in total could provide meaningful credit in a construction industry Australian Apprenticeship.
Career outcomes: Builder’s labourer
Subject or unit name 1: Work effectively and sustainably in the construction industry
Subject or unit name 4: Carry out measurements and calculations
Subject or unit name 5: Read and interpret plans and specifications
Subject or unit name 6: Use construction tools and equipment
Subject or unit name 7: Apply basic levelling procedures
Subject or unit name 9: Carry out concreting to simple forms
Subject or unit name 10: Apply OHS requirements, policies and procedures in the construction industry

Courses: Prepare to work safely in the construction industry
Description: This unit of competency specifies the mandatory work health and safety training required prior to undertaking construction work. The unit requires the person to demonstrate personal awareness and knowledge of health and safety legislative requirements in order to work safely and prevent injury or harm to self and others. It covers identifying and orally reporting common construction hazards, understanding basic risk control measures, and identifying procedures for responding to potential incidents and emergencies. It also covers correctly selecting and fitting common personal protective equipment (PPE) used for construction work.
Career outcomes: This unit is a pre-requisite to entry to all construction worksites
Subject or unit name 1: Prepare to work safely in the construction industry/white card

Courses: Certificate I in Conservation and Land Management
Description: This qualification is an entry-level qualification aimed at individuals entering the conservation and land management industry. It allows individuals to develop basic skills and knowledge to prepare for work. They may undertake a range of simple tasks under close supervision. The range of technical skills and knowledge is limited.
Career outcomes: There are no specific job outcomes to this qualification, but the skills achieved will assist in successfully undertaking a Certificate II pre-vocational program for job outcome, or will facilitate entry into and Australian Apprenticeship.
Subject or unit name 1: Work safely
Subject or unit name 4: Recognise fauna
Subject or unit name 5: Recognise plants
Subject or unit name 6: Observe and report plants or animals
Subject or unit name 7: Apply chemicals under supervision
Subject or unit name 9: Work effectively in the industry
Subject or unit name 10: Participate in workplace communications

Description: This qualification provides an occupational outcome in conservation and land management. Work would be carried out under general guidance and supervision. The qualification enables individuals to select an Indigenous land management, conservation earthworks, lands, parks and wildlife or natural area management context as a job focus or a mix of these.
Career outcomes: The following job roles are defined for this course: / Conservation Earthworks Trainee Pest Management Assistant (Feral Animals) / Landcare Assistant / Parks and Wildlife Officer / Indigenous Land Management Assistant

Description: This qualification provides a general vocational outcome in the conservation and land management industry. The qualification enables individuals to select an Indigenous land management, lands, parks and wildlife or natural area management context as a job focus or a mix of these.
Career outcomes: Job roles and titles can vary at different workplaces. They could include: / Leadership roles as an Indigenous ranger / National parks worker / Revegetation worker or a land rehabilitation worker

Courses: Certificate III in Early Childhood Education and Care
Description: This qualification reflects the role of workers in a range of Early Childhood Education settings who work within the requirements of the Education and Care Services National Regulations and the National Quality Standard. They support the implementation of an approved learning framework, and support children’s wellbeing, learning and development. Depending on the setting, educators may work under direct supervision or autonomously.

Subject or unit name 3: Identify and respond to children and young people at risk

Description: This qualification reflects the role of early childhood educators who are responsible for designing and implementing curriculum in Early Childhood Education and care services. In doing so they work to implement an approved learning framework within the requirements of the Education and Care Services National Regulations and the National Quality Standard.

City: Batchelor Campus, Desert People’s Centre Campus
Courses: Diploma of Education
Description: The Qualification provides the opportunity for education workers to broaden their skills and knowledge base in the field of education support work. The qualification covers workers in a range of education and school settings who provide assistance and support in the classroom to facilitate student learning in collaboration with teachers and working with students under broad based supervision.
Career outcomes: The qualification occupational titles may include: / Teacher Assistant / Education Worker / Tutor / Homeland teaching assistant / Education assistant (special needs) / Teacher aid / Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education officer.

City: Batchelor Campus, Desert People’s Centre Campus, Central Australian communities
Courses: Certificate II in Family Wellbeing
Description: The Certificate II in Family Wellbeing is a program that addresses the physical, mental, emotional and spiritual issues that impact on an individual’s wellbeing, family unity and community harmony. The aim of the Certificate II in Family Wellbeing is to address unresolved personal and community issues, which can impact on individuals and families throughout their lives. These can manifest in grief and trauma, suicide and other forms of selfharm, identity issues, use of alcohol and other drug problems, family violence and over representation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in the justice system.
Career outcomes: It provides learners with the skills and knowledge to: / Take ownership of and address their personal issues / Seek relevant support and assistance / Develop the self-confidence to enter vocational training, employment or further education.
Subject or unit name 1: Communicate effectively
Subject or unit name 2: Understanding self and improving personal interactions
Subject or unit name 4: Addressing challenging behaviour
Subject or unit name 5: Understanding and recognising psychological health
Subject or unit name 6: Integrating principles of wellbeing
Subject or unit name 7: Managing stress
Subject or unit name 9: Accessing community and government support services

Courses: Certificate II in Aboriginal and/ or Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care
Description: This qualification reflects the role of workers who undertake a range of tasks under direct supervision to support the provision of primary health care services to Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander clients and communities. Such work will be performed as part of a health clinic, centre or service. This qualification is suited to Australian Apprenticeship pathways and is appropriate for delivery within VET in Schools programs. No licensing, legislative or certification requirements apply to this qualification at the time of publication.
Career outcomes: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health worker
Subject or unit name 1: Comply with infection prevention and control policies & procedures
Subject or unit name 4: Work with Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander clients and communities
Subject or unit name 5: Support clients to obtain access to health services
Subject or unit name 6: Provide basic health information to clients
Subject or unit name 7: Perform work role in Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander primary health care context
Subject or unit name 9: Transport individuals
Subject or unit name 10: Provide nutrition guidance for specific health care

Courses: Certificate IV in Aboriginal and/ or Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care
Description: This qualification reflects the role of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander people working to provide a range of support roles to Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander clients and communities, including specific health promotion programs, advice and assistance with selfmanagement of chronic illness These workers can be expected to flexibly assume a variety of job roles and undertake a broad range of tasks either individually or as a member of a multidisciplinary team.
Career outcomes: Job roles of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Health Workers vary greatly from the Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Health Workers may perform their work roles in a range of settings: / Health clinics, services and hospitals. / Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations (ACCHOs). / Rural and remote locations, either through these services, or as visiting services
Subject or unit name 1: Comply with infection prevention and control policies and procedures
Subject or unit name 2: Participate in workplace health and safety
Subject or unit name 4: Provide first aid
Subject or unit name 5: Work in a ATSI primary health care context
Subject or unit name 6: Facilitate and advocate for the rights and needs of community members
Subject or unit name 7: Undertake basic health assessment
Subject or unit name 9: Plan, implement and monitor health care in a PHC context
Subject or unit name 10: Deliver PHC programs for ATSI communities

Courses: Certificate IV in Aboriginal and/ or Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care Practice
Description: This qualification reflects the role of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander people working to provide a range of clinical primary health care services to Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander clients and communities, including specific health care programs, advice and assistance with, and administration of, medication. These practitioners can be expected to flexibly assume a variety of job roles and undertake a broad range of tasks either individually or as a member of a multidisciplinary team. This qualification addresses the specific legislative responsibilities of Aboriginal and/ or Torres Strait Islander Health Practitioners and is required for national registration with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Practice Board of Australia within Australian Health Practitioner Regulatory Agency (AHPRA).
Career outcomes: Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Health Practitioners may perform their work roles in a range of settings: / Health clinics, services and hospitals. / Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations (ACCHOs). / Rural and remote locations, either through these services, or as visiting services.
Subject or unit name 1: Comply with infection prevention and control policies and procedures
Subject or unit name 2: Participate in workplace health and safety
Subject or unit name 4: Provide first aid
Subject or unit name 5: Work in a Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander primary health care context
Subject or unit name 6: Facilitate and advocate for the rights and needs of community members
Subject or unit name 7: Assess client’s physical wellbeing X 5 blocks
Subject or unit name 9: Plan, implement and monitor health care in a PHC context
Subject or unit name 10: Deliver PHC programs for Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander communities

Courses: Diploma of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care Practice
Description: This qualification is specific to Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander people working to provide a range of primary health care services to Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander clients. The Diploma of Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care Practice defines the knowledge and skills for workers involved in Aboriginal and/ or Torres Strait Islander Primary Health Care and who work autonomously under the broad guidance of others. The Diploma qualification covers workers who have a basis of skills and knowledge in primary health care practice, which they may apply in clinical, management or education functions.
Career outcomes: Aboriginal and/or Torres Strait Islander Health Workers may perform their work roles in a range of settings: / Health clinics, services and hospitals. / Aboriginal Community Controlled Health Organisations (ACCHOs). / Rural and remote locations, either through these services, or as visiting services.
Subject or unit name 1: Provide first aid
Subject or unit name 2: Implement and monitor infection prevention and control policies and procedures
Subject or unit name 4: Work legally and ethically
Subject or unit name 5: Work in a ATSI primary health care context
Subject or unit name 6: Provide nutrition guidance for specific health care
Subject or unit name 7: Assess client’s physical wellbeing X 5 blocks
Subject or unit name 8: Plan, implement & monitor health care in a PHC context
Subject or unit name 9: Deliver PHC programs for ATSI communities
Subject or unit name 10: Administer medications

Courses: Provide Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR)
Description: This unit describes the skills and knowledge required to perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) in line with the Australian Resuscitation Council (ARC) guidelines. This unit applies to all workers who may be required to provide CPR in a range of situations, including community and workplace settings. To maintain currency, this unit needs to be revised and reassessed annually.
Career outcomes: All jobs where staff are required to have CPR skills to perform their job role.
Subject or unit name 1: Provide Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR)

Courses: Provide an emergency First Aid response in an education and care setting
Description: This unit describes the skills and knowledge required to provide a First Aid response to infants, children and adults. The unit applies to educators and support staff working within an education and care setting who are required to respond to a first aid emergency, including asthmatic and anaphylactic emergencies. This unit of competency may contribute towards approved First Aid, asthma and anaphylaxis training under the Education and Care Services National Law and the Education and Care Services National Regulations (2011). To maintain currency, this unit needs to be revised and reassessed every three years. The CPR section requires annual renewal.
Career outcomes: There are no job roles defined for this course
Subject or unit name 1: Provide an emergency First Aid response in an education and care setting

Courses: Course in Immunisation Training for Aboriginal Health Workers and Aboriginal Health Practitioners
Description: The unit develops skills and knowledge required of an immunisation health worker to prepare for an immunisation clinic, manage the vaccine cold chain, consult with clients and provide immunisation information and administer and promote immunisation in Aboriginal communities in accordance with relevant state/territory and national legislation and guidelines. The unit applies to the Aboriginal Health Worker and Aboriginal Health Practitioner working independently or in a team conducting the immunisation service
Career outcomes: / Immunisation Health Worker
Subject or unit name 1: Deliver Immunisation services in Aboriginal communities

Courses: First Aid
Description: This course describes the skills and knowledge required to perform Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) in line with Australian Resuscitation (ARC) guidelines; recognise and respond to life threatening emergencies and provide a First Aid response to a casualty. The course applies to all workers who may be required to provide an emergency first aid response in a range of situations, including community and workplace settings. To maintain currency, this course need to be revised and reassessed every three years. The CPR unit requires annual renewal. Students must demonstrate at least two continuous minutes of CPR on an adult manikin on the floor and an infant on a hard surface. Students will be issued a Statement of Attainment on the successful completion of all three units.
Career outcomes: There are no job roles defined for this course.
Subject or unit name 1: Provide cardiopulmonary resuscitation

Courses: First Aid for Early Childhood and Education
Description: This unit describes the skills and knowledge required to provide a first aid response to infants, children and adults. The unit applies to educators and support staff working within an education and care setting who are required to respond to a first aid emergency, including asthmatic and anaphylactic emergencies. This unit of competency may contribute towards approved first aid, asthma and anaphylaxis training under the Education and Care Services National Law and the Education and Care Services National Regulations (2011). To maintain currency, this unit needs to be revised and reassessed every three years. The CPR section requires annual renewal.
Career outcomes: There are no job roles defined for this course.
Subject or unit name 1: Provide Cardio Pulmonary Resuscitation
Subject or unit name 4: Provide an emergency first aid response in an education and care setting

Courses: Certificate I in Automotive Vocational Preparation
Description: This qualification is an introductory qualification to the automotive retail, service and repair industries and an entry to further training in several sectors. Courses: Certificate I in Engineering
Description: The minimum requirements for achievement of the Certificate I in Engineering are: / Completion of all of the core units of competency listed below, and / Completion of elective units listed below to the value of at least 24 points. Points associated with prerequisites count towards the total (refer to units and prerequisites listing in Appendix 2, Volume 1). Appropriate elective units to the value of 5 points may be chosen from other endorsed Training Packages and accredited courses where those units are available for inclusion at Certificate I. Note that the elective units listed below include all of the units that are approved for selection from the MEM Training Package for use qualification. This meets the NQC requirement that one sixth of the total units must be able to be selected from other qualifications in the same Training Package.
Career outcomes: This course will prepare participants with skills and knowledge of welding and fabrication.
Subject or unit name 1: Apply principles of occupational health and safety in the work environment
Subject or unit name 2: Plan to undertake a routine task

Courses: Certificate II in Resources and Infrastructure Work Preparation
Description: This qualification reflects the roles of individuals who perform mainly routine tasks and procedures, using limited practical skills and fundamental operational knowledge, and taking some responsibility for the quality of the work outcomes.
Career outcomes: / Other Construction and Mining Labourers
Subject or unit name 1: Work safely and follow WHS policies and procedures
Subject or unit name 3: Identify and assess environmental and heritage concerns
Subject or unit name 4: Carry out measurement and calculation
Subject or unit name 5: Use hand and power tools
Subject or unit name 6: Cut, weld and bend materials
Subject or unit name 7: Plan and organise work
Subject or unit name 9: Trim and cut felled trees

Courses: Certificate II in Civil Construction
Description: This qualification reflects the role of individuals working in an operational role in civil construction, who undertake a prescribed range of tasks using limited practical skills and fundamental knowledge, in a defined context working under supervision.
Career outcomes: / Earthmoving Plant Operators
Subject or unit name 1: Plan and organize work
Subject or unit name 3: Identify, locate and protect underground services
Subject or unit name 4: Read and interpret plans and specifications
Subject or unit name 5: Carry out manual excavation
Subject or unit name 6: Spread and compact materials manually
Subject or unit name 7: Communicate in the workplace
Subject or unit name 9: Operate small plant and equipment
Subject or unit name 10: Work safely and follow WHS policies and procedures

Courses: Certificate III in Civil Construction Plant Operations
Description: This qualification reflects the role of a skilled operator working with civil construction plant, who applies a broad range of skills in a varied work context, using some discretion and judgement and relevant theoretical knowledge. The individual may provide theoretical advice and support a team.
Career outcomes: / Earth Moving Plant Operator (General)
Subject or unit name 1: Plan and organise work
Subject or unit name 3: Identify, locate and protect underground services
Subject or unit name 4: Read and interpret plans and specifications
Subject or unit name 5: Carry out manual excavation
Subject or unit name 6: Support plant operations
Subject or unit name 7: Spread and compact materials manually
Subject or unit name 9: Communicate in the workplace
Subject or unit name 10: Handle resources and infrastructure materials and safely depose of nontoxic materials

Courses: Certificate I in Visual Arts
Description: This qualification reflects the role of individuals who are developing fundamental creative and technical skills that underpin visual arts and craft practice.
Career outcomes: / Community arts workshop assistant
Subject or unit name 1: Contribute to health and safety of self and others
Subject or unit name 3: Use ideas and techniques to develop creative work
Subject or unit name 4: Develop painting skills
Subject or unit name 5: Develop skills in textile work
Subject or unit name 6: Develop understanding of own Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Identity

Courses: Certificate II in Visual Arts
Description: This qualification reflects the role of individuals who are developing the basic creative and technical skills that underpin visual arts and craft practice.
Career outcomes: Art studio trainee / Community arts workshop assistant
Subject or unit name 1: Contribute to health and safety of self and others
Subject or unit name 4: Source and use information relevant to own arts practice
Subject or unit name 5: Develop drawing skills
Subject or unit name 6: Develop ceramics skills
Subject or unit name 7: Develop printmaking skills
Subject or unit name 8: Identify fibres, fabrics and textiles used in the TCF industry
Subject or unit name 9: Apply dyeing techniques to produce Indigenous textile designs

Courses: Certificate III in Visual Arts
Description: This qualification reflects the role of individuals who are developing a range of visual art skills and who take responsibility for own outputs in work and learning. Practice at this level is underpinned by the application of introductory art theory and history.
Career outcomes: Art studio technicians / Practising artist / Studio trainee / Art worker trainee / Textiles studio trainee
Subject or unit name 1: Contribute to health and safety of self and others
Subject or unit name 2: Develop drawing skills to communicate ideas
Subject or unit name 4: Apply knowledge of history and theory to own arts practice
Subject or unit name 5: Produce work that expresses own Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander identity
Subject or unit name 6: Produce paintings
Subject or unit name 7: Produce textile work
Subject or unit name 9: Produce sculpture
Subject or unit name 10: Produce ceramics
